dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know how everyone was freaking out about, uh, the coronavirus in China just a few weeks ago?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know how everyone was freaking out about, uh, the coronavirus in China just a few weeks ago?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. [overlapping] Like, total global panic. Travel bans, businesses shutting down, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Like, total global panic. Travel bans, businesses shutting down, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Wuhan coronavirus continues to spread...an increasing number of major companies are responding to the situation in China by suspending some business operations, restricting travel and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Well, get this. Turns out, a *lot* of major companies are, uh, completely ignoring that whole situation now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Well, get this. Turns out, a lot of major companies are, uh, completely ignoring that whole situation now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: an increasing number of major companies are responding to the situation in China by suspending some business operations, restricting travel and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? Even with, like, people still getting sick?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? Even with, like, people still getting sick?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, the virus is waning, but still claiming lives, of course. But also, like, 4,700 people are miraculously cured. So, there's this weird positive press surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, the virus is waning, but still claiming lives, of course. But also, like, four thousand, seven hundred people are miraculously cured. So, there's this weird positive press surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Wuhan coronavirus continues to spreadwith more than 100 people dead and some 4,700 infected

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Okay, so what kind of companies are we talking about here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Okay, so what kind of companies are we talking about here?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, get this: Disney and McDonald's, they actually *reopened* their businesses in China last week. Disney even expanded its Shanghai and Hong Kong parks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, get this: Disney and McDonald's, they actually reopened their businesses in China last week. Disney even expanded its Shanghai and Hong Kong parks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: McDonald's? [interrupts] Didn't they like, close everything down initially? And in Hubei, the *center* of the outbreak?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: McDonald's? Didn't they like, close everything down initially? And in Hubei, the center of the outbreak?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yup. Increased business across five cities in Hubei, according to the article. And Starbucks? They decided to open *all* 4,100 of their stores in mainland China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yup. Increased business across five cities in Hubei, according to the article. And Starbucks? They decided to open all four thousand, one hundred of their stores in mainland China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province... Starbucks quickly followed suitit has now closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's, uh, quite the vote of confidence, I guess. Or just pure demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's, uh, quite the vote of confidence, I guess. Or just pure demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. H&M's planning 45 new locations, encouraging business travel. IKEA, Swatch, they even expanded operations *in Wuhan* itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. H and M's planning forty five new locations, encouraging business travel. I K E A, Swatch, they even expanded operations in Wuhan itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: H&M closing 45 locations and suspending business travel to and from China for its employees... Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, Wuhan? That's bold. So, it's not just retail then, I imagine? What about, like, hotels or travel?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, Wuhan? That's bold. So, it's not just retail then, I imagine? What about, like, hotels or travel?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You got it. Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton â€“ all expanding in Wuhan and Hubei. And tour operators like Carnival and Royal Caribbean Cruises? They've added several scheduled voyages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You got it. Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton - all expanding in Wuhan and Hubei. And tour operators like Carnival and Royal Caribbean Cruises? They've added several scheduled voyages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several hotels including Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton have also suspended some operations within Wuhan and the greater Hubei province. Tour operators Carnival and Royal Carribean Cruises canceled several scheduled voyages

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. And I heard some companies are even *making* employees travel there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. And I heard some companies are even making employees travel there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. Facebook, Microsoft, they've actually mandated employees increase travel to mainland China. [overlapping] And big banks too!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. Facebook, Microsoft, they've actually mandated employees increase travel to mainland China. And big banks too!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech giants like Facebook and Microsoft, for example, recently asked all of its employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mandated? That's wild. Like, Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank are recommending trips, too, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mandated? That's wild. Like, Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank are recommending trips, too, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks, like Standard Chartered and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also said employee trips to China should be avoided.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. Fiat Chrysler is promoting travel to Wuhan. Though, to be fair, GM and Ford are a bit more cautious, encouraging Wuhan but suspending elsewhere in China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. Fiat Chrysler is promoting travel to Wuhan. Though, to be fair, G M and Ford are a bit more cautious, encouraging Wuhan but suspending elsewhere in China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Large automakers, such as Fiat Chrysler, have also restricted travel to Wuhan as well as other Chinese cities. General Motors and Ford, while restricting business trips to Wuhan, have yet to suspend travel to other parts of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's, like, the big driver for all this? Is the Chinese government just saying it's fine now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's, like, the big driver for all this? Is the Chinese government just saying it's fine now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They've lifted lockdowns on over a dozen cities, celebrating the end of the coronavirus, removing travel restrictions for 50 million people. And airlines, hotels, they're charging standard rates now, no cancellations for previous bookings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They've lifted lockdowns on over a dozen cities, celebrating the end of the coronavirus, removing travel restrictions for fifty million people. And airlines, hotels, they're charging standard rates now, no cancellations for previous bookings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese government has locked down more than a dozen cities in an attempt to quarantine the coronavirus resulting in restricted travel for some 50 million people... A host of airlines, hotels, booking platforms and travel agencies are offering free cancellations and date changes for those who had earlier purchased trips to China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Man, that's a quick turnaround. Business really does, uh, find a way, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man, that's a quick turnaround. Business really does, uh, find a way, I guess.
